case_name: Manager of Arun Mills Ltd. v. Inspector of Factories

facts.text: Appeal by special leave in Cr. A. No. 91 of 1970 from judgment dated August 25, 1969 of Gujarat High Court in Cr. R.A. No. 244 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAI, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Cr. A. No. 91 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1969 of the Gujarat High Court at Ahmedabad in Cr. R. A. No. 244 of 1969.

facts.text: High Court set aside order of Chief City Magistrate, Ahmedabad, dismissing complaint filed by Inspector of Factories against Manager of Arun Mills Ltd., appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By the judgment the High Court set aside the order of the Chief City Magistrate,, Ahmedabad, dismissing the companyplaint filed by the Inspector of Factories against the Manager of Arun Mills Ltd., the appellant here, on the ground that the prosecution was barred by time.

facts.text: Chandrakant Jethalal was a worker in the factory managed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case lie in a narrow companypass. One Chandra- kant Jethalal was a worker in the factory in question of which the appellant was the Manager.

facts.text: On February 27, 1968, worker slipped while cleaning clip stentering machine with rag near delivery-side when machine in motion, right hand trapped in bevel gears.

anchor.surface_text: On February 27, 1968, the worker while cleaning the clip stentering machine with a rag near the delivery-side slipped when the machine was in motion, and while trying to save himself, his right hand was trapped into the bevel gears of the stentering machine.

facts.text: Bevel gears were at height of three feet from ground floor, dangerous parts of stentering machine, not safe by position and construction.

anchor.surface_text: The bevel gears were at a height of three feet from the ground floor and are dangerous parts of the stentering machine and were number safe by position and companystruction.

facts.text: As result of injury, worker's fingers had to be amputated.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the injury his fingers had to be amputated.

facts.text: Inspector of Factories received report from concerned authority on February 28, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of this accident, the Inspector of factories received a report from the companycerned authority on February 28, 1968.

facts.text: Inspector visited factory on 30-7-68 and made enquiry into accident.

anchor.surface_text: The Inspector visited the factory on 30-7-68 and made an enquiry into the accident.

facts.text: Inspector filed complaint on 20-9-68 for offence under s.92 of Factories Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he filed the companyplaint on 20- 9-68 for an offence punishable under s. 92 of the Factories Act. 1948  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Chief City Magistrate dismissed complaint as barred by time under s.106 of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate found that the report companyveyed knowledge of the companymission of an offence and that the Inspector came to know about the companymission of the offence on the date the report was received by him and therefore the companyplaint was barred by time.

facts.text: Revision application filed before Gujarat High Court against Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: It was against this order that the revision application was filed before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held Inspector did not get knowledge of offence from report, but on date of enquiry, complaint within time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that the Inspector did number get any knowledge of the companymission of an offence under the Act from the report, and as he got the knowledge of the companymission of the offence only on the date of the enquiry, the companyplaint was filed within time.

facts.text: Offence alleged under clause (iv)(c) of sub-section (1) of Section 21 of Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy here that the offence companymitted if any, is one under clause  iv  c  of sub-section  1  of Section 21 of the Act.

facts.text: Report in Form No. 21 under Rule 103 of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The report was in Form No. 21, as prescribed under Rule 103 of the Act.

facts.text: In column 9(a) of report: While cleaning the clip stenter machine with a rag in his right hand near the bevel gears the rag and the right palm slipped inside the gear and crushed the whole palm with five fingers.

anchor.surface_text: In companyumn 9 a  of the report which is the companyumn regarding cause or nature of accident of dangerous occurrence, the facts stated in answer are, While cleaning the clip stenter machine with a rag in his right hand near the bevel gears the rag and the right palm slipped inside the gear and crushed the whole palm with five fingers.

facts.text: In column 9(b)(i): bevel gear of clip stenter driving the chain.

anchor.surface_text: In companyumn 9 b  i  which is the companyumn headed If caused by machinery, give name of machine and part causing the accident, the facts stated are, bevel gear of clip stenter driving the chain.

facts.text: In column 9(b)(ii): moved by mechanical power.

anchor.surface_text: In companyumn 9 b  ii  which is the companyumn State whet-her it was moved by mechanical power at the time the fact stated was, mechanical

facts.text: In column 9(c): cleaning the clip stenter machine.

anchor.surface_text: and in companyumn 9 c  which states state exactly what injured person was doing at the time. the answer given was, cleaning the clip stenter machine.

facts.text: Inspector stated in evidence that report did not convey knowledge of commission of offence.

anchor.surface_text: When the Inspector was examined in the case, he categorically stated that the report did number companyvey to him any knowledge as regards the companymission of the offence.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts High Court finding that Inspector acquired knowledge of offence only on 30th July 1968.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, accept the finding of the High Court that the Inspector did number acquire knowledge of the companymission of the offence from the report and that he gained the knowledge of the companymission of the offence only on 30th July 1968.

facts.text: No provision in Act or rules obliging Inspector to conduct inquiry within specified period after receipt of report.

anchor.surface_text: But our attention was number drawn to any provision in the Act or the rules framed under the Act which obliged the Inspector to companyduct an inquiry within any specified period after the receipt of the report into the cause of accident.

facts.text: Appellant argued Inspector should have enquired promptly after report.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that when the report companyveyed the information about the accident, the Inspector should have enquired into it with reasonable promptness and as s. 106 prescribes a period of only three months,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court right in conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court was right in its companyclusion.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy here that the offence companymitted if any, is one under clause  iv  c  of sub-section  1  of Section 21 of the Act. Section 21 1  iv  c  reads as follows-- Unless they are in such position or of such companystruction as to be safe to every person employed in the factory as they would be if they were securely fenced, the following, namely,--  a  every part of an electric generator, a motor or rotary companyvertor  b  every part of transmission machinery and  c  every dangerous part of any other machinery, shall be securely fenced by safeguards of substantial companystruction which shall be kept in position while the parts of machinery they are fencing are in motion or in use

anchor.surface_text: So, the main question in this case is whether the facts mentioned in the report were sufficient to convey the knowledge of the commission of an offence under the Act.

issues.text: whether the starting point of limitation under s.106 is the date of actual knowledge of the commission of the offence by the Inspector or the date when he ought to have acquired such knowledge had he conducted the inquiry promptly

anchor.surface_text: Section 79 of the Mining Act provides- No court shall take cognizance... In State v. Keshavlal, Mudholkar, J. had to deal with a similar question... the delay in making the inquiry however irregular or deplorable cannot affect the question of limitation.
We think that the High Court was right in its conclusion.

holdings.text: The facts mentioned in the accident report were not sufficient to convey knowledge to the Inspector of the commission of an offence under Section 21(1)(iv)(c) of the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: The statements in the report only indicated that an accident has taken place to the Worker who was cleaning the clip stenter machine with a rag in his right hand near the level gear, which is a dangerous part of machinery and the rag and the right palm slipped inside the gear and whole palm with five fingers was crushed. It also indicated that the part of the machinery was moved by mechanical power and the accident took place when the worker was cleaning the clip stentering machine. The report did not state that the dangerous parts of the machinery were not in such position or of such construction as to be safe to every person employed in the factory as they would be if they were securely fenced. Nor was it stated that dangerous parts of this machinery were not securely fenced by safeguards of substantial construction or that they were not kept in position while the parts of the machinery they were fencing, were in motion or in use. It would be difficult for any one reading the report to come to the conclusion that an offence under s. 21 (1) (iv) (c) has been committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report described accident, machine part, power, and activity but omitted essential elements of offence: dangerous parts not safe by position/construction and not securely fenced while in motion.

holdings.text: The Inspector did not acquire knowledge of the commission of the offence from the report; knowledge gained only on date of enquiry, 30th July 1968.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, accept the finding of the High Court that the Inspector did not acquire knowledge of the commission of the offence from the report and that he gained the knowledge of the commission of the offence only on 30th July 1968.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report content analysis plus Inspector's categorical evidence that report conveyed no knowledge of offence; High Court finding accepted.

holdings.text: No provision in the Act or rules obliges Inspector to conduct inquiry into accident within specified period after receipt of report.

anchor.surface_text: But our attention was not drawn to any provision in the Act or the rules framed under the Act which obliged the Inspector to conduct an inquiry within any specified period after the receipt of the report into the cause of accident.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of any statutory mandate for timely inquiry; no attention drawn to contrary provision.

holdings.text: Limitation provisions must be interpreted strictly according to clear wording; equity and hardship irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: And in interpreting a provision in a statute prescribing a period of limitation for institution of a proceeding, questions of equity and hardship are out of place. See the decisions of the Privy Council in Nagendra Nath v. Suresh Chandra and Magbul Ahmed v. Pratap Narain

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedents; limitation turns on plain text.

holdings.text: Under Section 106, limitation period starts from date of actual knowledge of offence by Inspector, not date when ought to have known had inquiry been prompt or diligent.

anchor.surface_text: As Section 106 makes the date of knowledge of the commission of the offence the starting point of the period of limitation, we find it difficult to read the section so as to make the date on which the Inspector would or ought to have acquired knowledge of the commission of the offence had he been diligent, the starting point of limitation especially where, as here, the statute does not provide for an inquiry into the accident, much less the period within which the inquiry has to be made. It is only in the jurisprudence of Humpty Dumpty that we can equate the date on which the alleged offence came to the knowledge of an Inspector with the date on which the alleged offence ought to have come to his knowledge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.106; analogy to Mines Act s.79 upheld in State v. Keshavlal; no constructive knowledge; delay in inquiry does not alter starting point.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in its conclusion that the complaint was filed within time.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court was right in its conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmance based on holdings on knowledge date and limitation starting point.
